Engineer Major Roy McBride of Las Cruces, New Mexico, says he’s not afraid of the challenge: IMAGE OF FOUR YOUNG MEN and TWO YOUNG WOMEN, seated on a SOFA, in a nondescript office environment with an Army Co of Engineers logo/graphic on a screen behind them. One of them is ROY MCBRIDE. Roy McBride: forties, handsome. His eyes are light blue, seemingly friendly, but reveal little about the man himse He is even-tempered, but one would not call him kind; the is an icy quality to him. Still, he is not overtly cruel petty, and to talk to him, one could never question his intentions or his integrity. Roy speaks slowly, formally, deliberately, as though he d not want ever to repeat himself. He seems guarded, sincer precise, competent. His face is blank but prone to the occasional awkward joke, and those jokes are made almost self-amusement. He does not seem morose. In fact, he smiles all the time, and his face often ligh with little motivation. He speaks with a very slight Midwestern/Western accent. Think Neil Armstrong. As he speaks, on the screen appears the title “Maj. Roy C McBride”.

The Army Corps of Engineers trains us to deal with our fears. And this team here is real inspiring-- Lt. Parsegian did a repair skywalk during an episode of pulmonary edema. Now when you see something like that, you just wanna get up there and do it as good as she did. Be part of that team. So we all feed on each other in that way.

McBride is only the latest ina long line of aerospace pioneers. His father, noted activist and educator H. Clifford McBride, was part of an astronaut colony tragically lost in space eighteen years ago. It is CLIFFORD MCBRIDE whom we’re LOOKING AT. Looks somew like Bill Clinton in that old Georgetown photo--almost li countercultural figure, a_ sharp contrast with Roy's butt down appearance.

My Dad was...he was certainly a different kind of astronaut. He was a free-thinker. He went all the way to Neptune. It didn’t end up going the way he wanted, but he’s the reason I do what I do. I just think you can’t worry too much about the past because you don’t have control over it. So I look forward. And like I said, we've certainly got ourselves a helluva team here.
(cheerful again) That team is always on the go. (MORE )
REPORTER’S VOICE (CONT'D) In the clouds, it’s all about the work, and one gets the sense that Roy would rather be left alone to perform his duties than talk to this reporter:
What I want...is to serve, to do my job as good as I can, away from the spotlight. It’s real critical to maintain control and not to be vulnerable to outside factors.
Roy flashes that smile.

With all of the risks, do you ever contemplate the larger meaning of what it is you're trying to accomplish? How we may be able, for example, to detect intelligent life out there, and find out what they might have to say to us?

No...not really... That’s not for me to comment on--I don’t consider that sort of thing. (the smile returns) But...I do thank you for your interest in the program, and we hope your continued support leads to our success. ANGLE ON ROY as we: FADE OUT.

Not in space, certainly earthbound, but frighteningly high up--higher than any aircraft we’ve ever been inside of. We move outside, above a small PLATFORM.

We're in the outer reaches of the atmosphere--around 100 thousand feet in the air. The ground far below is both bl where the waters are, and tawny, where the land is. The earth’s curvature is beginning to be apparent. The air is frigid and thin, and the environment hostile. there is no doubt it is beautiful. Control--I have not yet completed my tasks--— Suddenly: along the entire length of the tether to which is attached, the busses’ ACTIVATION LIGHTS come on, one b one. Roy can see the tether is becoming active, section after section, at breakneck speed--and he pushes himself away f it at the last second, just as it ACTIVATES. (beat) Control, do you read? NO ANSWER. Then, as he descends: ROY STRETCHES HIS ARMS and LEGS OUT In the DENSER AIR, HE STOPS THE SPIN.

At last, Roy straightens himself out. Like a great skydiv HE PULLS THE RIPCORD... A PARACHUTE shoots out from the back of his suit and open with tremendous force, YANKING HIM UP and AWAY FROM US. He RIGHTS HIMSELF and begins to float safely to the earth
Roy sinks to the surface. A WIDE SHOT as we SEE: SCORES o PEOPLE RUNNING TO HELP HIM... MAN’S VOICE (PRE-LAP) I must say, you seem to be in remarkably good shape, Major.

How d’you feel?

Well...my left shoulder’s a little sore. It was likely hyperextended at some point during descent. MED TECH #1 (CONT’D) Yeah, you got yanked around pretty good. But you’re in one piece. (beat) Sad to say, some of your fellow engineers weren't so fortunate.
(beat) What’s that, sir?
We lost your support crew, on the wire--and four hundred some odd more here on earth, too. Been tragic.
Gee... That’s real unfortunate. I’m real sorry to hear that...  10.
Would you like the shades down, Major?

No, it’s okay. I like to observe the, the cloud patterns and the mountains. The Med Tech hears this, nods, then TYPES something into small iPad-type device, except it unscrolls. The CAMERA TILTS UP the ELECTRONIC DOCUMENT TO SEE: “MILD AUTISM”. As the Med Techs pack up, Med Tech #1 holds an earplug-si item.
(hands Roy the earplug) You might want to put this in your ear, sleep with it overnight. Just to check for any head trauma. And try to stay put, if you can.
Yessir. I would like to be able to return to my work.
[If] Your head checks out, you can be cleared to go back as soon as tomorrow.
Okay. I’d like that very much. Given all that’s occurred, they’re probably pretty shorthanded up there.
(stares for a beat; then) Of course. Try to rest. He packs up and leaves.

Roy is in bed, sitting up in hospital whites. A GREEN LIG and a BUZZ to his left. He PUSHES A BUTTON. PROJECTED in front of him, a very advanced form of FaceTime is showing His mother. LEANNE MCBRIDE. Late sixties. Seems older tha her age; her face is lined, her mouth slightly downturned  11. She SEES him, EXPLODING WITH EMOTION. The sound is worse the image, for some reason:
Roy! TEARS FLOW FORTH from HER:
Thank the Good Lord! I couldn’t lose you up there too. You’re all I've got...
Hello, Ma. I’m all right. I’m gonna go back to work soon.
I love you--so much. I was just so sick with worry--
(smiles) There’s no reason for any kind of concern. The fuss is unnecessary.
Oh Lord... I know you don’t understand--you can’t. Maybe someday you will... I’m sorry you're alone there...
It’s okay. (beat) I prefer it.
I love you, Roy. You’ll always be my little one. Maybe I can see you for Thanksgiving?
It’s possible. Goodbye, Ma.
Goodbye, darling. He PUSHES A BUTTON and it SHUTS OFF the image...

The room is DARK. ROY is prostrate, in bed, asleep. RESTLESS. We HEAR his PULSE, HIS HEART... Roy’s EYES OPEN, and he is COVERED IN SWEAT. His EYES WID like he’s SEEING A GHOST. AWAKE, he has a VISION. FLASHING: An image appears to him, and to us: The striking eyes and most of the face of a YOUNG BOY. He seems around 8 years- old, looking off-screen at something. His pa abating somewhat, he allows his head to REST back, ON THE PILLOW. His EYES DART BACK AND FORTH, looking out to the ceiling--and to the heavens... FADE OUT.

Major, I’m Brigadier General Fallon. This is Lieutenant General Sharpe, Director of SPACECOM Special Operations. And Adjutant General Vogel.
(nods; then) Sirs. Ma’am. The DOOR is CLOSED BEHIND THEM. Actually, more SEALED THA CLOSED. Fallon motions for Roy to sit, and he does as wel As the others sit around him, he’s looking at a file:

Please--sit down. Your profile’s certainly very interesting. You've done exceptionally well on the assessment tests. Says here-- you've got a near-photographic memory. Basic combat...space training, too--just exceptional, ‘cross the board.
(subtly prideful) Thank you, sir.

It’s what we’re trained for, sir. I can’t take any personal credit for that.
You know Major, generally we look for people like you, people who won't let emotions or fears get in the way of a task. (MORE )
People who might be called “on the spectrum,” if you will. I do say that with respect. (beat) So you must not be surprised that we've reached out to you.
No, sir...I expected a debriefing on account of the accident. (beat) I am surprised that Ops is handling it, but it’s certainly not a problem of any kind.

Well, we’ve traveled a long way to see you here today. And it is not a coincidence. The full-wall VIDEO SCREEN behind Roy plays real-time ima of Fort Carson. Lieutenant General Sharpe consults his PD device. Fallon stares at Roy for a moment, then:
General, we’re ready.

(nods; then back to Roy) Major, this is not about your accident--at least, not directly. (beat) We have...something of a highly classified nature to show you. Major, what do you know about the Lima Project? A TURN. Roy FREEZES for A SLIGHTLY PERCEPTIBLE MILLISECON

Do you remember how his departure affected you? It WAS a one-way mission, was it not?

My, my mother has often expressed her devastation by his abandonment. (beat) It’s the consensus that his departure was unforgivable. Roy lets loose a small laugh(!). An AWKWARD BEAT. Major?  19.
(finally; clears throat) My father is...alive, sir?

We believe so. The Lima Project’s A.I. is still online, and as you know, this would indicate crew has survived. We must ensure they can do no further harm. As such, your relationship to him is potentially invaluable to us.
Yes sir...

ROY now ventures to SEE, on both sides: WINDOWS, through which we can spot the INTERIOR of the LI PROJECT. As Roy makes some final adjustments to his equipment, we notice one of the very small robots on the side of the A- Frame. A CAMERA mounted on it silently ROTATES towards Ro and a RED LIGHT blinks on next to the camera. It knows Ro is here. Roy LOOKS RIGHT INTO IT:

I am Major Roy McBride. Do you read. I am attempting to reach Dr. McBride. AGAIN, no ANSWER. ROY PLACES EXPLOSIVE CHARGES on the DOORFRAME of the LIMA STATION. They BLOW. Just then, an APERTURE on the station opens up. ROY VENTU INSIDE. LIKE HE IS ENTERING A DREAM.  97. INT. LIMA PROJECT —- DORMITORIES HUMAN BODIES are FLOATING, gravity-free. The FLUORESCENT LIGHTS FLICKER. We STILL HEAR ONLY ROY’S BREATHING. LOUD, PRESENT. We ARE COMPLETELY INSIDE HIS HEAD. Roy finds himself inside a KITCHEN-TYPE area, which is ho somewhere within a laboratory. There are machines and equipment and tables and sinks, but no people besides Roy There’s ZERO GRAVITY here.
A DOOR IS OPEN, revealing a dark PASSAGEWAY lit only by B LIGHT.
Roy enters/floats into it. ALL OF A SUDDEN, ALL THE MONIT on each side--and there are several--switch on. THE LIGHT BRIGHTEN. ON THE SCREENS: ROY’S FATHER! DR. H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE. Roy HALTS:

This will be the final message recorded by the Lima Project. Our efforts have come to an end, and its entire story must be told in the hopes that someday it will be known. ROY MOVES CLOSER TO THE SCREEN. It is his FATHER, virtual seeming to speak from the dead: H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE (CONT’D) We came here to pursue mankind’s most noble goal: the search for intelligent life beyond the Earth. But our telescope has repeatedly confirmed only the singular importance--and ephemerality--of our moon, oceans, and magnetic field. After extensive analysis, we now confirm that we are entirely alone in the reachable universe. We shall no longer honor false gods; there is no intelligent life elsewhere, and the rage of the cosmos will destroy us in time. (MORE )

H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE (CONT’D) For this reason, we on the Lima Project had begun to devise a plan for a new system--with galaxies, stars, and planets. We dreamed to be the first lifeform to make the universe anew. CLOSE ANGLE ON ROY MCBRIDE.
Roy CLIMBS the STEPS. We STILL HEAR, CONTINUING:

With the vast stores of antimatter we have discovered here, our research focused on the creation of a new big bang. Such a project would take perhaps several thousand years to develop. But only such a bold, long-term endeavor would untether us from the earth and ensure the permanent survival of our species.

Roy FLOATS TOWARD the Control Center. Like the Control To of a large airport, it’s somewhat dark--but everything is Multiple MONITORS, SCREENS, GAUGES, etc., all like a symp of blinking, fluttering color and light.

Our research is contained on the onboard VD recorder. It is the most extensive set of data ever assembled about the visible universe. This must be brought back to Earth so that our scientists can be convinced to act. However, our computer system is currently preventing all outside communication. As it is charged only with the continued pursuit of intelligent life, it has been unable to adapt to our changed prerogatives. All attempts to reprogram it have failed. With no alternatives, we sought to return to the Earth.  99. Roy looks around at the many screens in front of him; the are like SECURITY CAMERAS, constantly cutting from one an to another. ONE ANGLE REVEALS: A SPACECRAFT, with a GANTRY. MODEST SIZE. CLOSE SHOT ON

ROY SCANS THROUGH BASIC BLUEPRINT PLANS of the LIMA PROJE CRAFT. INT. DATABANKS —- LIMA PROJECT It is ROWS of DATA, stored. A CLOUD for all the informati collected by the Project. Roy FLOATS THROUGH IT, approaching TWO LARGE ORANGE STEEL CANNISTERS: “VOYAGE DATA RECORDER” He PULLS THEM OUT FROM THE FRAME. Over this, we STILL HEAR: H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE (CONT’D) A craft was assembled from 3-D- printed parts, piece by piece, out of view of the onboard system. But it was recognized upon completion, and our nuclear fuel has been intentionally destroyed by the system. This resulted in the catastrophic destruction of moon Larissa. All of us have suffered severe radiation poisoning. Brain death is imminent. The onboard system will likely maintain only our organ function in order for it to remain operational.
CLOSE SHOT: “DR. CLIFF MCBRIDE”. A PAPER TAB, HANDWRITTEN On the DOOR of his LIVING QUARTERS. Roy FLOATS INTO/ENTERS the LIVING QUARTERS.

We hope we will be mourned by a Mother Earth that dared send so many of her sons and daughters into the unknown. In ancient days, human beings looked at stars and saw their heroes in the constellations. In modern times, our heroes have become creatures of flesh and blood. (MORE )

Others will follow us, and surely find their way home. Our mission must not be denied. HE LOOKS AROUND. He SEES the SPACE. It is MODEST, with SCIENCE BOOKS, and DIARIES, and FAMILY PHOTOS everywhere, pinned on the WALLS. Then we HEAR Francesca’s VOICE, more PRESENT than CLIFFORD McBRIDE’S had been: FRANCESCA’S VOICE “The brain is wider than the sky, for, put them side by side, the other will include, with ease, and you beside...” (beat) It’s so beautiful... Do you want to hear another one...? Then, APPEARING: FRANCESCA! SEATED, SOMEHOW STILL OBEYING GRAVITY as ROY FLOATS! She STARES, saying nothing.
Roy doesn’t know what to do, or say. He STOPS HIS MOVEMEN He lifts his ARM toward her... She GETS UP, begins to WALK TOWARD ROY! !
NEAR HIM NOW, HE REACHES OUT, and...

head_text.subj: HIS HAND AND ARM GO RIGHT THROUGH HER

text: THROUGH HIM, sits down at the other end. Roy LOOKS AROUND THE SPACE and SEES NOW that it’s like hi home where he grew up, his home from pictures. PROJECTED. IT’S ALL HOLOGRAMS. He SEES: HIMSELF, as a CHILD, on the FLOOR, PLAYING WITH TRUCKS. And his MOTHER, LEANNE, YOUNGER. His HAND can go right through them, too. (As ROY FLOATS, these HOLOGRAMS remain “earthbound”; that they seem to have “gravity”.) Roy TURNS BACK to LOOK AT FRANCESCA. She is in conversati with someone “offscreen,” smiling, looking lovely and war and everything an idealized version of her would be. CLOSE ANGLE ON ROY. We HEAR the PITTER-PATTER of RAIN. RAIN? ALL OTHER SOUND DROPS OUT. And we:

A lowered gray sky. Deserted. A monastery on the UPPER WE SIDE of NEW YORK’S MANHATTAN ISLAND. A PORTCULLIS. COBBLESTONES. The VIDEO we saw, yes, but now we are “here in the space. A GROUP of children PLAY. ADULTS speak to each other, standing behind the children, watching them play, making small talk. The scene has a strange, dare we say, unearth quality to it. There is a distance to it; not an emotiona distance, but a visual distance. A haze, almost. A dreamlike quality. A SMALLER GROUP of adults, and two children, are here, to They are nearby and yet somehow apart. We SEE: ROY’S MOTHER, LEANNE. Much YOUNGER. She seems PREOCCUPIED, though she smiles a lot as she attends to th children. Also here is some other woman we don’t know, ab Leanne's age. She is completely quiet, almost nervous, as she watches the children play. Then there is H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE, who is involved with t children, making hats for them, drawing for them, joking them. AMONG THE CHILDREN: the young ROY. And the young FRANCESC (though she is older than Roy--she seems around 16 or 17, around 8). She has a grin from ear to ear; Roy does not, instead dedicated to whatever he seems to be DRAWING. H. Clifford McBride stops clowning with another child and moves to Roy’s side. Warmly:
Roy? (beat) Roy? (to Young Francesca) He gets very involved in what he’s doing.
(a laugh; a smile) It’s okay.
Sweetheart, I need you to listen to me for just a moment--you can go back to your drawing very soon. Roy finally looks up--for just a brief beat.  102. H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE (CONT’D) This is Francesca.
(ebullient) Hello!
(back to his drawing) Hi.

She’s someone...very close to me, someone I really care for. I want you to meet her--I think you'll really like her. Roy keeps drawing--AND THEN TURNS HIS BACK TO HER A BIT. H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE (CONT’D) It’s not so easy for Roy to meet new people. It’s something we’re trying to work on with him. (quieter) We’re hoping he’1ll break through it someday... Clifford approaches Roy. Not unsympathetically, he touche his son and attempts to communicate an important lesson a human interaction: H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE (CONT’D) (to Roy) When someone talks to you, you say hello, you look them in the eye. You listen, and you ask how they are--you don’t want them to think you don’t care about them. Roy REACTS IMMEDIATELY. He starts to get teary out of embarrassment and awkwardness. Sensing this, she moves to comfort him:

It’s okay, you can go back to your drawing. He just wanted us to meet. Roy then eyes her directly, and without a word. She looks his drawing. Warmly: YOUNG FRANCESCA (CONT’D) That's a wonderful picture. Is that a rocket?  103.
(nods; then) My father goes into space.
That’s where I’m from.
(looks up, interested now) Where?
I’m from Mars. Which is really, really far.
Yeah. Sometimes it’s more than 140 million miles away. But right now it’s only 80 million miles.
(again with a laugh) I didn’t know that!
Are you by yourself there?

No, but it feels like that sometimes. That’s why I’m so glad I met you. UNEXPECTEDLY, responding to her kindness to such a degree can overcome his shyness, he hands his drawing to her. Francesca looks at the drawing and she is very moved. TEA OF HAPPINESS come to her eyes. Roy STARES at the tears as though they are foreign objects. The SWELL OF EMOTION fro her is as strange as anything he has seen. YOUNG FRANCESCA (CONT’D) Oh--thank you so much! That’s so sweet of you! It’s beautiful! She gives him a BIG, TENDER HUG. Roy ALLOWS HIMSELF to be “crushed” by the hug. Roy's FATHER BEAMS...
A chamber that appears almost like an old “Iron Lung” machine. Roy APPROACHES IT. CLOSE SHOT: “MCBRIDE, CLIFFORD, 788919-0323” It’s a small, illuminated medical identification card. WI

ROY, COMING UPON his FATHER’S BODY, inside what looks lik kind of ELECTRONIC SARCOPHAGUS. Dr. H. Clifford McBride exists in a vegetative state, res in a large silver CASE. Through glass, we can SEE that hi EYES ARE slightly OPEN, his BODY HOOKED UP to LIFE SUPPOR SYSTEMS. MONITORS around the case MEASURE his PULSE and other VITA SIGNS. He is KEPT COLD. ROY moves to it, OPENS THE SARCOPHAGUS. STARES AT HIS FATHER’S LOBOTOMIZED FACE. He LIFTS his FATHER’S STIFF, LIFELESS BODY out of its electronic SARCOPHAGUS, pulling off the DIODES and IVs wh keep him “alive”. When the body EMERGES from the SARCOPHAGUS, it seems almo to FLOAT STANDING STIFFLY UPRIGHT. It starts SPINNING IN WEIGHTLESSNESS. ROY GRABS the SPINNING BODY, in a way that becomes an EMBRACE. PULLING THE BODY WITH HIM, he FLOATS BACK OUT...

ROY releases his FATHER’S BODY INTO SPACE, PUSHING IT TOW the SURFACE of NEPTUNE. IN the DISTANCE, WE SEE H. CLIFFORD McBRIDE’S BODY drift TOWARD a RING AROUND NEPTUNE. The BODY comes in contact with a SMALL ICE ROCK. It SHATT INTO A MILLION PIECES. LIKE BROKEN WINDSHIELD GLASS. Almost at the VERY INSTANT that H. CLIFFORD McBRIDE’s BOD destroyed, LIGHTS COME ON in a formerly DARKENED SECTION the LIMA CRAFT.
A spacecraft which remains DOCKED. It has been constructe for Dr. Clifford McBride’s return, presumably. It NOW HUM WITH LIFE.

Roy enters the cockpit, HOLDING the ORANGE VDR ("VOYAGE D RECORDER”) CANNISTERS. Examining the craft’s SYSTEMS, he and we recognize that i astonishingly similar to the Cepheus. (The spacecraft are all constructed by 3-D PRINTER, and there is a uniformity their design and construction.) The entire SYSTEM of the CRAFT COMES TO LIFE, ONLINE. AS DOES: RADIO STATIC FROM THE EARTH! Communication has b restored:

head_text.subj: ROY PRESSES THE RADIO BUTTON, TURNS DIALS FOR A CERTAIN C

text: SpaceCom. This is Major Roy McBride. I have taken it upon myself and have reached the Lima Project; all crew are deceased. I have recovered significant material for analysis, which I am now in the process of forwarding to you. The self-replicators here malfunctioned and must be destroyed to prevent any unforseen further catastrophe. Therefore, I’m inputting target coordinates 34.34 North, 81.92 West from Earth standard vector 100. (beat) I’m going to attempt a return to the earth now. The onboard system indicates I’1l be arriving in approximately 41 days and 9 hours. My journey will have kept me in an isolated state for a considerable period by that time. I...I am very much looking forward to the day that solitude ends. Over. He FLIPS OFF THE RADIO. He PULLS DOWN on a LARGE LEVER which looks almost like th kind of control switch for a 747 airplane.  106. He moves around the CAPSULE, OBSERVING a PRINTED CHECKLIS Adjusts SEVERAL SWITCHES.

Roy is SETTLING IN to his COCKPIT SEAT. He is about to PU an OXYGEN MASK ON. He activates the CRAFT’s GYROSCOPES an CONTROL STICK. Then: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) Outgoing mail. McBride, Roy M. Send to Leanne McBride. He SEES an IMAGE of HIS MOTHER. It’s a photo of her, with him as a little boy. A little ANIMATED BEE flies around t picture, making a PUTT-PUTT SOUND. ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) Record voice message. After a BEEP--Roy begins to record his message. As we kno he’s not much one for communicating--especially when emot are concerned. But here... ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) Mother, I’m on a classified mission right now. (beat) I am by myself. THE CAMERA SLOWLY--almost imperceptively so--PUSHES INTO ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) (equivocating; then he steels himself) I am attempting now to return to the earth. In the event I cannot, I don’t want you to wonder about me. (beat) I'd like to express to you that I realize that you gave me an excellent childhood. I am grateful to you now for attempting to nurture friendships and other relationships. Perhaps you don’t think I remember much, but I do. Sometimes the smell of certain foods will bring back exceedingly pleasant memories... On this mission I’ve encountered people who knew father. (MORE )

He stops. HIS HEAD. 107. ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) I don’t know how much you know about this, but it appears he had another child, a daughter named Francesca. We both met her once. She and I talked. She informed me that father acted out of the noblest principles. And that he sacrificed himself in the name of science. TEARS WELL UP AGAIN. He CLOSES HIS EYES and BOWS Then begins to speak again: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) Mother, I, I was unable to protect her. I regret this--terribly. Even worse than I regret any negative feelings toward father. It’s led me to commit acts that you would condemn--but were required by circumstance. It has forced me to be alone, a situation I now find unacceptable. (exhales; regroups) But I have succeeded in my mission. I want to say goodbye now, and whatever occurs on my return, I am forever your loving son. He SHUTS OFF the RECORDER. ANGLE ON THE FROZEN IMAGE of ROY’S MOTHER.
The Craft’s GANTRY RELEASES the ship. Slowly. The CRAFT begins to move, its ROCKETS FIRING. Almost at the same time: A BEAM, HIGH-INTENSITY, HITS A P
It EXPLODES! In SILENCE. The colors of the explosion, set
against the DEEP BLACKNESS of SPACE.
Then another SILENT and COLORFUL EXPLOSION.

Roy looks through his windows to SEE: A SERIES OF LASERS HITTING VARIOUS PARTS of the STATION a TELESCOPE.  108. In SILENCE, the EXPLOSIONS ARE VAST, FEROCIOUS, and someh oddly BEAUTIFUL. They ILLUMINATE the dead BLACKNESS of SPACE even as they utterly destructive, devastatingly so.
Roy’s ROCKET starts to STAGE, AFTER its initial BURST. It leaves the CONTINUED DEVASTATION of the LIMA PROJECT in i wake as it PROPELS FORWARD.
Roy’s HEAD SHAKES TO AND FRO; the ROCKET’S FORCE is ASTONISHING.
The CRAFT FIRES a NEW SET OF ROCKETS. It moves on, deeper and deeper and deeper toward the earth. The RADIO PIPES U and it’s in the most straightforward, almost banal, tone imaginable:

Major McBride, this is SpaceCom. We have verified the authenticity of your coordinates and have begun to target sites accordingly. Upon reentry to earth’s orbit, we will intercept your craft and you will be debriefed. However, we do acknowledge the potential of your data files to transform rather radically our view of what the universe may hold. (beat) We wish you godspeed on your journey homeward. US SPACECOM out. Finally, Roy’s ROCKET disappears from our view, hurtling toward the EARTH. The End
